awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The leaky rake to solid plate transition on flow through biological filtering structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Numerous small organisms that swim, fly, smell, or feed in flow rely on branched, bristled and hairy structures that are significant to biological and biomedical applications. The movement and orientation of such bristled layers can change the behavior of the air or water flow through them such that they may act as either solid plates or leaky rakes. Understanding how animals creatively take advantage of this type of flow transition could inform the design of filters and sampling devices. Although such flows have been studied in many systems, predictive mathematical models of the leaky rake to solid plate transition remain unavailable. The goal of this project is to reveal the physical mechanisms behind this transition through mathematical modeling and experimentation. The theoretical models developed could find applications in biomedical problems such as the flow of lymph and blood through porous tissues and vascular protective layers. In terms of education and outreach, students will be trained at the interface of engineering, mathematics, and biology through interdisciplinary courses, field research, and multidisciplinary group meetings. Diverse students will be recruited through the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP).

This research will elucidate the fundamental fluid dynamics of biological and bioinspired filtering arrays operating at the mesoscale, where inertial and viscous forces are nearly balanced. It will also reveal the fundamental physics of particle capture and exchange when advection and diffusion are nearly balanced. Two types of marine invertebrates will be examined: 1) upside-down jellyfish that drive flow through 3D bristled oral arms, and 2) sea fans that are branched into approximately 2D sheets. Modeling the leaky-to-solid transition is challenging due to the need to simultaneously resolve small-scale flow around micron-scale structures and bulk flow around centimeter-scale arrays. New mathematical models, informed by experiments, will be developed to describe the effective porosity of flexible filtering layers. Particle capture rates and concentration profiles around mesoscale filtering arrays will be quantified experimentally in organisms and physical models. Further details of chemical exchange will be resolved numerically using the immersed boundary method. In terms of biology, these organisms represent one of many examples where particle capture and nutrient uptake occur in mesoscale bristled arrays. Revealing how this strategy is advantageous contributes directly to the NSF Rules of Life. In terms of bioinspired design, these systems exhibit inherently multiscale solutions for filtering and exchange that will provide new insights into the bioinspired design of filtering structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Coral reefs are a vital part of the ocean's ecosystems. Corals such as sea fans, with large branching structures, play an important role in establishing shelters for other reef organisms and reestablishing disturbed areas. These corals can affect the flow through and around themselves to generate areas of circulation to enhance feeding or to allow fluid to pass more freely through the structure, reducing stress on the organism. This project studies the fluid dynamics of these filtering structures at small scales. This work focuses on marine organisms like upside-down jellyfish and sea fans to understand how their structures enhance prey capture and nutrient exchange. Our research explores the transition from solid to leaky configurations in these structures to investigate general questions related to bulk flow, small-scale flow patterns, and their impact on chemical exchange and particle capture associated with basic biological functions. Our findings show that marine organisms can alter the flow in the surrounding environment and through their appendages through relatively small reconfigurations in their structures. This ability to affect the surrounding flow has implications for enhancing feeding, facilitating waste removal, and reducing forces experienced by the organisms. Bristled filtering structures operating in the range of micrometer to centimeter scales have evolved to perform processes such as feeding and sensory functions.

The specific goals of the project involve developing mathematical models to investigate these flexible filtering appendages and their ability to alter the flow in their environment through reconfiguration. To address the research aims, quantitative measurements of live organisms were used to construct physical and experimental models. Computational and numerical methods were employed for comparison and analysis. Specifically, 3D printed physical models and dye visualization of the physical models were compared to computational experiments using finite element methods. The models investigated fluid flow between the branches of corals and through the individual polyps distributed along the branches to understand how the flow changes at different spatial scales. 

We found that branches can either act as leaky rakes or solid plates depending upon the size of the gaps between the branches. The polyps and pinnules mostly impede the flow at the smaller spatial scales. Our results indicate that sea fans and other branching corals can noticeably alter the flow through their structures through the extension and retraction of the polyps, which adjusts the size of the gaps in the branches. At particular scales commonly found in the branching structures, these modest changes in configuration can lead to large differences in flow velocities and forces experienced by the corals.   Through these results, we have gained more of an understanding of the important role the smallest structures (the polyps) play in affecting and directing the bulk flow around and through the overall organism.

We also modeled the fluid dynamics of nematocysts (stinging cells) used by cnidarians for particle capture. The projectile structures associated with these stinging cells are some of the fastest-accelerating biological structures and are essential for cnidarian (corals, anemones, jellyfish) predation and defense strategies. Preliminary findings suggest that such high accelerations are necessary to overcome the forces dominating at the cellular level and allow nematocysts to fire their projectiles at these small scales successfully. These findings contribute to our understanding of the ballistic strategies organisms employ at the cellular level for basic functions including stinging behavior. These results also give insight into bioinspired design for targeted delivery systems at small scales.

This project included student training, cross-disciplinary education, and the development of educational materials for university and high school students and teachers. This award supported summer research for four undergraduate students, during which they gained experience working with laboratory specimens, analyzing video footage, developing mathematical models in MATLAB, analyzing data, and presenting results. Pedagogical materials developed as part of this award are accessible to the public through the laboratory websites of the principal investigators and GitHub repositories.


Last Modified: 11/02/2023
Modified by: Christina L Hamlet
